title: Teen, 15, survives 100-foot fall off cliff into water off Guam
text:
CLOSE A Guam Fire Department rescue boat docks at the Gregorio D. Perez Marina in Hagåtña with a 15-year-old boy who was rescued after falling approximately 100 feet down from a lookout along the Johnstown cliffline in Tamuning and into the ocean below on Oct. 8, 2019. Jasmine Stole Weiss and Rick Cruz/PDN, Pacific Daily News

HAGATNA, Guam – A 15-year-old boy reportedly fell about 100 feet from a cliff into the water off Guam on Tuesday. He suffered serious injuries but was alert and conscious when first responders reached him, according to Guam Fire Department officials.

A crew on a rescue boat pulled the boy from the water, said Kevin Reilly, a Guam fire spokesman and firefighter. The crew took him to the Hagatna marina and then to a waiting ambulance to take him to the hospital.

The boy had multiple lacerations and injuries to his head and body from the fall from Jonestown Cliff, said Assistant Fire Chief Daren Burrier.

Burrier said rescue units responded quickly to Tamuning on the western side of Guam, which was to the boy’s benefit.

A 15-year-old boy is secured to a gurney by Guam Fire Department personnel in preparation for him to be taken to the hospital Tuesday, Oct. 8, 2019, after the boy fell approximately 100 feet from a cliff in Tamuning, Guam. (Photo: Rick Cruz/PDN)

Medics transported the boy from the rescue boat to a stretcher at the Hagatna boat basin. They wheeled him into the waiting ambulance. He had a blue sheet wrapped around most of him, save for his bare feet and bandaged head.

The boy was stable on the way to the hospital, Burrier said.

Beer name: Marshall Islands says beer named after Bikini Atoll unacceptable

Ocean conditions in the Mariana Islands, which Guam is a part of, were particularly threatening Tuesday with a super typhoon in the area. Guam, which is in the western Pacific Ocean, is about 5,802 miles west of San Francisco and nearly 1,600 miles east of Manila, Philippines.

Super Typhoon Hagibis passed over Anatahan at 1 a.m. local time Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service. By 10 a.m., Hagibis was moving away from the Marianas.

But Hagibis’ influence in the region remained.

Burrier cautioned residents to heed the weather services’ advisories. He said the skies may clear up and the sun might be out in the next few days, but the water will still be rough.

The weather service had issued a high surf warning and a high surf advisory Tuesday for Guam and Rota. The high surf advisory is in effect until about Friday morning.

A high surf advisory means that dangerous, battering waves will pound the shoreline and make for life-threatening conditions, according to the advisory.

High surf will affect all beaches and produce “dangerous swimming conditions,” according to the National Weather Service.

Follow Jasmine Stole Weiss on Twitter: @StoleJasmine

Read or Share this story: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/10/08/teen-survives-fall-off-guam-cliff/3906652002/
description: The 15-year-old boy had multiple lacerations and injuries to his head and body, but he was alert and conscious when responders reached him.
